name: Educational Platform for Teachers - Iterative Double Diamond
description: Complete Double Diamond showing iteration: first diamond too broad, second diamond zoomed into specific problem area (grading workflow)

inputs.context: EdTech platform for K-12 teachers. First diamond explored entire classroom management workflow (planning, instruction, assessment, communication). Discovery revealed grading as critical pain point. Second diamond zoomed into grading workflow specifically
inputs.initialResearch: Teacher interviews (n=50), classroom observations (n=20), time-tracking study of teacher workflows

discovery.keyInsight: Teachers overwhelmed by non-teaching tasks. Grading identified as single biggest time drain and source of stress
discovery.evidence: Teachers spend 12 hours/week grading (vs. 8 hours planning, 25 hours teaching). 89% say grading is 'overwhelming' or 'unsustainable'
discovery.scopeTooLarge: Initial discovery covered entire classroom workflow. Too broad to converge on actionable problem

definition.initialProblemStatement: Teachers struggle to manage all aspects of classroom workflow due to time constraints
definition.issueWithStatement: Too broad. Could lead to unfocused solution trying to solve everything
definition.iterationDecision: Zoom in on grading workflow for second diamond. Highest impact, most clearly defined problem

userInsights.insight: Grading writing assignments is time-consuming not because of scoring, but because of providing meaningful feedback
userInsights.evidence: Teachers spend average 12 minutes per essay: 2 min scoring, 10 min writing feedback comments
userInsights.userQuote: I can tell if it's an A or B paper in 30 seconds. But then I spend 10 minutes writing comments to help them improve. That's where the time goes

userInsights.insight: Teachers have internalized grading rubrics and criteria but spend time articulating feedback
userInsights.evidence: Teachers identify issues instantly ('weak thesis', 'needs evidence') but spend minutes crafting constructive comment
userInsights.userQuote: I know immediately what the problems are. But I need to write it in a way that's encouraging and specific enough to help them improve

userInsights.insight: Teachers want to provide feedback but worry AI grading will devalue their expertise
userInsights.evidence: 75% interested in time-saving tools, 68% concerned about AI replacing teaching judgment
userInsights.userQuote: I don't want a robot grading my students' essays. But if it could help me give better feedback faster, I'm interested

userInsights.insight: Same feedback comments get written over and over across different students
userInsights.evidence: 65% of feedback comments are variations on 20 common themes ('needs stronger thesis', 'add evidence', etc.)
userInsights.userQuote: I feel like I'm writing the same comments over and over. But I can't just copy-paste - each student needs personalized feedback

problemAreas.description: Teachers spend disproportionate time articulating feedback they've already identified
problemAreas.userImpact: 10+ hours/week writing feedback, evening and weekend work, burnout

problemStatement.statement: K-12 teachers providing feedback on student writing assignments struggle to sustain the time commitment because articulating constructive, personalized feedback for each student takes 10+ minutes per paper, resulting in evening/weekend work, burnout, and reduced feedback quality as teachers fall behind
problemStatement.who: K-12 teachers, especially in writing-heavy subjects (English, History)
problemStatement.what: Struggle to provide timely, quality feedback on writing assignments
problemStatement.why: Articulating feedback is time-consuming despite teachers identifying issues quickly
problemStatement.when: After every major assignment, several times per month
problemStatement.impact: 12 hours/week grading, burnout, delayed feedback, less writing assigned

designPrinciples.principle: Augment Teacher Judgment, Don't Replace It
designPrinciples.rationale: Teachers must remain in control of grading decisions. Technology assists but doesn't decide
examples: AI suggests feedback, teacher reviews and edits
Teacher approves all scores and comments
Clear attribution: 'Assisted by AI, reviewed by [teacher name]'
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: Slower than full automation, but maintains teacher agency and trust

designPrinciples.rationale: Imperfect personalized feedback beats perfect generic feedback
examples: Customize AI-suggested feedback with student name and specific examples
Reference student's previous work and growth
Maintain teacher's voice and encouragement style
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: Requires student history and teacher voice modeling

designPrinciples.rationale: Time savings should enable better feedback, not just less time grading
examples: Use saved time to add more specific examples
Provide feedback on more aspects of writing
Spend time on encouraging comments alongside critique
designPrinciples.tradeoffs: Must measure quality improvement, not just time savings

successCriteria.measurement: Student surveys on feedback usefulness + expert review
successCriteria.target: 4.5/5 usefulness rating (maintain or improve from current 4.2)

successCriteria.measurement: Number of writing assignments per semester

concepts.name: Feedback Phrase Library
concepts.description: Library of teacher's own feedback comments, searchable and customizable for quick insertion
concepts.howItWorks: System learns teacher's common feedback phrases. When grading, teacher searches library ('thesis') and selects relevant phrase, then customizes for specific student

concepts.name: AI Feedback Suggestions
concepts.description: AI analyzes student writing and suggests feedback comments for teacher to review and approve
concepts.howItWorks: AI identifies writing issues (weak thesis, needs evidence, etc.) and generates feedback suggestions based on teacher's style. Teacher reviews, edits, approves

concepts.name: Collaborative Grading Sessions
concepts.description: Teachers grade together in real-time sessions, sharing feedback and building collective library
concepts.howItWorks: Department teachers grade together, can see each other's feedback (anonymized students), build shared feedback library, maintain consistency

concepts.name: Rubric-Based Auto-Feedback
concepts.description: Teacher defines detailed rubric, system generates feedback based on rubric scores
concepts.howItWorks: Teacher scores student on detailed rubric (thesis: 3/5, evidence: 4/5, etc.). System generates feedback explaining each score with improvement suggestions

concepts.name: Smart Feedback Assistant (Hybrid)
concepts.description: Combines AI suggestions with teacher phrase library and rubric alignment
concepts.howItWorks: AI analyzes writing and suggests issues + feedback. Teacher can accept AI suggestion, pull from personal library, or write custom. All feedback tagged to rubric criteria for transparency

ideationSummary.conceptRequiringValidation: Teacher trust in AI feedback quality and accuracy

selectedSolution.name: Smart Feedback Assistant
selectedSolution.description: AI-assisted feedback system that suggests comments for teacher review, learns teacher's voice, and aligns with rubrics while maintaining teacher control and judgment
selectedSolution.rationale: Balances automation benefits with teacher control. AI handles time-consuming articulation, teacher maintains judgment and personalization. Hybrid approach addresses automation anxiety
selectedSolution.valueProposition: Grade essays in half the time while improving feedback quality and maintaining your teaching voice

keyFeatures.description: AI analyzes student writing and identifies specific areas for improvement aligned with rubric
keyFeatures.userBenefit: Instantly see what needs feedback rather than reading to identify issues

keyFeatures.description: AI generates feedback comment suggestions in teacher's style for each identified issue
keyFeatures.userBenefit: Start with draft feedback to edit rather than writing from scratch

keyFeatures.description: Teacher reviews AI suggestions, edits for personalization, approves final feedback
keyFeatures.userBenefit: Maintain control and add personal touches to ensure quality

keyFeatures.description: System learns teacher's feedback style and common phrases for better suggestions
keyFeatures.userBenefit: AI suggestions sound like you, not generic robot feedback

keyFeatures.description: Reference student's previous work, growth trajectory, and learning goals in feedback
keyFeatures.userBenefit: Feedback shows you know the student, not just their current paper

implementationSteps.description: Pilot with enthusiastic teachers, gather feedback quality data, build trust
deliverables: AI model trained on teacher feedback samples
successCriteria: AI feedback quality rated 4+ by teachers

implementationSteps.description: Deploy issue detection and feedback suggestions with teacher review workflow
Add voice learning and student-specific personalization
successCriteria: 90% of AI suggestions require minimal editing

qualityAssurance.teacherInvolvement: Teachers are primary QA. Co-design with teachers throughout. Monthly teacher advisory board reviews

iterationLearnings.whyIterationNeeded: First diamond was too broad - 'classroom management' encompassed too many distinct problems. Couldn't converge on actionable solution
iterationLearnings.howScopeChanged: Zoomed in from 'entire classroom workflow' to 'grading writing assignments specifically'
benefitsOfIteration: Focused solution addressing concrete pain point
iterationLearnings.whenToIterate: When problem statement is too broad to generate focused solutions, when discovery reveals one area has disproportionate impact, when stakeholders can't align on priorities
